tossups.text: An angel predicts in Genesis that Ishmael will grow up to be like one of these animals. The name of Ramath-Lehi was given to a place where a man killed a thousand Philistines with the (*) jawbone of one of these animals. An angel with a sword caused one of these animals to turn away from the road, after which it reprimanded Balaam for beating it. Because Zechariah predicted that a future king would ride one of these animals, Jesus chose one of these animals to ride when entering Jerusalem. For 10 points, name these stereotypically stubborn beasts of burden.
tossups.answer: donkey [or ass; accept additional description such as “wild ass” if given] Note: as the incident involving Balaam shows, it is clear that the God of the Old Testament is the only known being which is capable of talking out of somebody else’s ass!

tossups.text: Several forms of this process, involving protein kinase A, were demonstrated in simple organisms like the sea hare Aplysia by Eric Kandel. Various kinds of this process were differentially impaired in Clive Wearing. The action of this process with new stimuli was studied on patient Henry (*) Molaison. The selectivity of this process is partially explained by spike-timing-dependent plasticity, which explains why long-term potentiation doesn't always occur. George Miller proposed that one kind of this process is limited by the "magic number" "seven plus or minus two." This process proceeds in the steps: "encoding," "storage," and "retrieval." tossups.text: Green proposed that this phenomenon occurs via his activation and inhibition model. A landmark study by Peal and Lambert examined the relation between this phenomenon and intelligence. The idea of multi-competence was developed to analyze people's measure of it. Its acquisition can be delayed by cross-meaning due to a type of "transfer." The distinction between the sequential and simultaneous forms of this ability depends on the time of acquisition of "L sub 2." People who possess this ability may be able to perform code-switching and may facilitate lexical borrowing. Communities marked by this phenomenon may exhibit diglossia or use a lingua franca. For 10 points, identify this ability of being proficient in more than one language.
tossups.answer: multilingualism [accept word forms; accept equivalents likepolyglots, bilingualism, or anything indicating speaking or learning a second language]

tossups.text: The last lines spoken in this play begin, "Our drooping country now erects her head, peace spreads her balmy wings, and plenty blooms." The first actor to perform this play's title character was Thomas Betterton. It was part of the standard theatrical repertoire until 1838, when William Charles Macready reverted it to a shortened version of the play on which it was based, fifteen years after Edmund Kean restored the tragic ending. tossups.answer: the sinking of the RMS Titanic [accept clear-knowledge equivalents]

tossups.text: The Reid method is used to calculate the vapor pressure of inputs and outputs for this process. Visbreaking is the reduction of the viscosity of straight run residues in this process, and those residues are separated in low pressure chambers via vacuum flashing. Long chain products of this process are broken down via FCC reactions to yield low boiling, low molecular weight products. After the inputs are passed through a boiler, this activity involves separating them through a fractional distillation tower, which captures light materials such as naphtha at the top. tossups.text: During the reign of Charles I, Archbishop Laud added this phrase to the Book of Common Prayer. Jesus is quoted as saying this phrase in the Book of Mormon, but whether the original text of the gospels quotes Jesus as saying this phrase is disputed. The first indisputable mention of this phrase is in a 2nd century text called the "Didache," or "Teaching of the Twelve Apostles", from which it may have been interpolated into the Byzantine type text of the gospels. During a Catholic mass, after the priest recites the Embolism, this phrase is said by both the priest and the congregation. This line is notably absent from the oldest manuscripts of Matthew 6:13, where one of Jesus's followers asks how to pray. For ten points, give the name of or recite this sentence that Protestants, but not Catholics, add to the end of the Lord's Prayer, which praises the might and majesty of God.
tossups.answer: the doxology [accept: "For thine is the Kingdom, the Power, and the Glory, Now and Forever" or "The Kingdom, the Power, and the Glory are Yours, Forever and Ever", or other clear equivalents/translations]

tossups.text: One method for detecting these objects features an amplification as a function of the normalized angular parameter u equal to u^2+2 over u times square root u^2+4. Another method to detect them employing a hydrogen fluoride tank to capture more precise spectra was developed by Campbell, Walker and Yang and uses variation in radial velocity. One hypothesis about a subset of these objects advanced by Ward and Brownlee rejects the principle of mediocrity by setting out conditions such as a circular orbit around the galactic center and a sufficiently large primary to prevent tidal locking. Gravitational microlensing is used to detect these objects, which are generally not terrestrial if they orbit population II stars, which prevents life from developing. For 10 points, name these objects, large bodies that revolve around stars other than the sun.
tossups.answer: extrasolar planets [or exoplanets; prompt on planets; prompt on anything about looking for stars that have planets that can host extraterrestrial life; accept clear-knowledge equivalents]

texts: Labov’s “gender paradox” says these people are more likely to lead language change from below, despite being more likely to conform to prestige variants when stigma is attached to a certain sound change.

In Language in the Inner City, Labov argues that these people’s namesake “Vernacular English” is a well-formed dialect following linguistic rules. One such rule governs use of the habitual “be” in these people’s sociolect, as in “Cookie Monster be eating cookies.”

One possible source of King Lear is John Florio's translation of this author's works into English. His ideas inspired a treatise on wisdom by Pierre Charron.

texts: Name this enigmatic Norse god of winter, a son of Sif and stepson of Thor.
Ullr is similar to this other Norse winter deity who went on skis. This giantess married Njord as compensation for the death of her father Thiazzi.

According to the Skaldskaparmal, the Aesir had to atone for Thiazzi's death by accomplishing this difficult feat, which Loki managed through a setup that involved attaching him to a goat by the testicles.
answers: making Skadi laugh [or equivalents that make it clear that Loki is causing laughter; prompt on entertaining Skadi; prompt on amusing Skadi]

texts: Identify this 6th century Byzantine emperor who issued the Corpus Juris Civilis and built the Hagia Sophia. His wife was Theodora.
Before being replaced by Narses, this general of Justinian the Great suppressed the Nika Riots and defeated the Vandal king Gelimer at the Battle of Tricamarum.
In 546, Belisarius was unable to prevent the Ostrogoths under Totila from performing this action, which had previously been done by Alaric I in 410 and Geiseric in 455.
answers: Justinian the Great (or Justinian I; prompt on “Justinian”)
sacking Rome (accept synonyms of “sack” like “capture;” accept clear equivalents) <JD>

bonuses.formatted_leadin: Answer these questions about Pentecostal Christianity, for 10 points each.
texts: The works of this aspect of God are emphasized greatly by Pentecostal Christians. This person of the Trinity is one with the Father and Son.
Pentecostals believe that this phenomenon can occur when a person is baptized or filled by the Spirit. The messages it produces are often incomprehensible to witnesses.

Like other Christians, Pentecostals practice this ordinance as modeled by Jesus in John 13. Practiced by many on Maundy Thursday, it involves kneeling down and humbling yourself by performing a potentially degrading task.
answers: Holy Spirit [or Holy Ghost; or Paraclete]
speaking in tongues [or glossolalia; or xenoglossy]
washing the feet of another person [accept answers which clearly indicate foot-washing; prompt on less specific answers such as "washing" or "bathing"]

texts: Name this force that is mediated by the W and Z bosons. It is responsible for radioactivity.
Caused by mass differences between photons and the W and Z bosons, this process led to the separation of the electroweak force at low enough energies.
Quarks with different values of this quantum number interact with the weak force differently. Up, down, charm, strange, top and bottom are the six different types of this for quarks.
answers: weak nuclear force [do not accept electroweak force]

texts: Name this tetralogy that includes Spring Snow and The Decay of the Angel, in which Shigekuni Honda encounters his friend Kiyoaki Matsugae's reincarnations as an accomplished young man, a princess, and an orphan.

This Japanese author wrote The Sea of Fertility. This author of Confessions of a Mask also described the former acolyte Mizoguchi's choice to burn down the title structure in The Temple of the Golden Pavilion.
After failing to inspire a military coup, Mishima performed this action. In a Sophocles play, Ajax performs this action with a blade that had been given to him by Hector.
answers: committing suicide [or seppuku; or any answer making it clear that he kills himself]
